title: Modeling Pulmonary Immunity:  Evaluation of the Innate Immune Response to Pathogens 1) Francisella tularensis 2) Mycobacterium tuberculosis and 3) Influenza A virus in mice (C57BL/6 and BALB/c)

producedBy.name: Modeling Pulmonary Immunity:  Evaluation of the Innate Immune Response to Pathogens 1) Francisella tularensis 2) Mycobacterium tuberculosis and 3) Influenza A virus in mice (C57BL/6 and BALB/c)

creators.name: University of Pittsburgh Center for Modeling Immunity for Biodefense

values.value: Analysis of local pulmonary and draining lymph node innate immune responses of mice and non-human primate (NHP) macrophage and dendrtitic cells to in vitro (and in vivo as indicated) infection with Francisella tularensis (in vivo - mice), Mycobacterium tuberculosis (in vivo - mice and NHP), and influenza A virus (in vivo- mice).  Data collection: gene expression, cytokine production, and cell activation and phenotype. Critical findings will be confirmed in human samples by in vitro analysis of human alveolar macrophages (from pateints undergoing bronchoscopy).   https://www.fbo.gov/index?s=opportunity&mode=form&tab=core&id=0ac9a8fad3e9c6286b6b3c59f899afac

primaryPublications.authorsList: Zinman G(1), Brower-Sinning R, Emeche CH, Ernst J, Huang GT, Mahony S, Myers AJ,  O'Dee DM, Flynn JL, Nau GJ, Ross TM, Salter RD, Benos PV, Bar Joseph Z, Morel PA.
primaryPublications.title: Large scale comparison of innate responses to viral and bacterial pathogens in mouse and macaque.

availability: Available for download after registration with ImmPort

distributions.title: Modeling Pulmonary Immunity:  Evaluation of the Innate Immune Response to Pathogens 1) Francisella tularensis 2) Mycobacterium tuberculosis and 3) Influenza A virus in mice (C57BL/6 and BALB/c)

acknowledges.name: University of Pittsburgh Center for Modeling Immunity for Biodefense

description: Alveolar macrophages from mice and macaques following infection with viral and bacterial pathogens were used to determine the similarities and differences to invading pulmonary pathogens
